answers.answer:
Ukrainian refugees can find information on enrolling children in various educational institutions, including kindergartens, schools, and after-school programs, with specific options provided by organizations like JRS Romania, Angel Appeal, and the "Ostrovok" Educational Hub, as well as online learning resources and a Ukrainian-language high school.

To find detailed information, visit the website https://dopomoha.ro/en/education-useful-information and read under the "education-useful-information" section.

To find detailed information, visit the website https://dopomoha.ro/en/education-useful-information and read under the "education-useful-information" section. For more details, visit https://dopomoha.ro/en/education-useful-information

answers.answer:
Ukrainian refugees can enroll their children in educational institutions by contacting specific organizations like JRS Romania, Angel Appeal Romanian Foundation, or the "Ostrovok" Educational Hub, which offer various educational programs. They can also enroll in the Taras Shevchenko Ukrainian High School in Maramureș.

To find detailed information, visit the website https://dopomoha.ro/en/education-useful-information and look for specific contact details and addresses under the sections for "JRS Romania," "Kindergarten by Angel Appeal Romanian Foundation," "The “Ostrovok” Educational Hub in Bucharest," and "Ukrainian secondary school Taras Shevchenko in Maramureș." The page also provides a link for general steps on how to enroll your child.

answers.answer:
Yes, JRS Romania offers educational programs including a kindergarten for preschool children and a school for first graders from Ukraine. They focus on preparing first graders for adaptation to Romanian schools and include Romanian language study.

You can find more detailed information by visiting the website https://dopomoha.ro/en/education-useful-information and looking under the section "Kindergarten and school from JRS Romania."

answers.answer:
The "Ostrovok" Educational Hub in Bucharest offers free classes for refugee students from Ukraine. These classes cover grades 0 to 11 in Sector 2 and grades 0 to 6 in Sector 4.

To find more detailed information, go to the website https://dopomoha.ro/en/education-useful-information and look under the section titled "The “Ostrovok” Educational Hub in Bucharest".

answers.answer:
Yes, classes at the 'Ostrovok' Educational Hub in Bucharest are free for Ukrainian refugee students.

To find this information, go to the website dopomoha.ro/en/education-useful-information and read under the section titled 'The “Ostrovok” Educational Hub in Bucharest'.

answers.answer:
No, the 'Ostrovok' Educational Hub in Bucharest does not certify children's studies. Children need to pursue online/family/external studies in Ukraine or enroll in a public school in Romania for certification.

You can find this information on the webpage https://dopomoha.ro/en/education-useful-information by scrolling down to the section titled "The “Ostrovok” Educational Hub in Bucharest."

Yes, there is a secondary school in Romania that teaches in the Ukrainian language, specifically the Taras Shevchenko Ukrainian High School located in Sighetu Marmației, Maramureș.

To find detailed information, visit the website https://dopomoha.ro/en/education-useful-information and look under the section titled "Ukrainian secondary school Taras Shevchenko in Maramureș."

answers.answer:
The Ukrainian Online School is a project by the Ministry of Education and Science of Ukraine, designed to provide free distance and mixed learning for students in grades 5-11. It offers video tutorials, tests, and self-study materials for core subjects.

To find more detailed information, go to the website https://dopomoha.ro/en/education-useful-information and read under the section "Online school from the Ministry of Education of Ukraine".
